note_text:
Admission Date:  [**2184-12-28**]              Discharge Date:   [**2185-1-4**]

Date of Birth:  [**2105-10-26**]             Sex:   F

Service: MEDICINE

Allergies:
No Allergies/ADRs on File

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 8263**]
Chief Complaint:
s/p MVC

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
intubated prior to transfer to [**Hospital1 18**]

History of Present Illness:
This is a 79 year old female with a history of who had a single
vehicle car accident on [**2184-12-28**].  The crash occured at low
speeds with no trauma noted to driver.  EMS arrived and noted
that the patient was altered and agitated and required
benzodiazepines for sedation.  She was transported to an OSH
where she was intubated to allow for CT imaging.  CT at OSH
suggested a question of a brain aneurysm or mass.  She was
hypotensive at the OSH and was started on phenylephrine; the
thought was she had dropped her pressures because of sedation.
She was quickly weaned off pressors, and then transferred to
[**Hospital1 18**] for further evaluation. Upon arrival to the ED at [**Hospital1 18**],
she had repeated imaging of her head which revealed no aneurysm
or bleed, however there was noted left sphenoid [**Doctor First Name 362**] meningioma
which is potentially chronic.  She was noted to be unresponsive
off sedation, with no response to sternal rub.  She was also
bradycardic to the 40s and hypothermic, requiring bair hugger.
A bedside echo was done which showed good contractility despite
the bradycardia.  Given a question of an elevated TSH at the
OSH, she received 500 mcg of T4 in the ED; she was then admitted
to the MICU for unresponsiveness.  At time of arrival to MICU,
her HR was 110, BP was 120/70, and she was hypothermic with temp
of 95.
Of note, upon review of her history briefly with family in ED,
they noted that she had increasing difficulty with walking,
talking, and motor activities sub-acutely over the past two
weeks.


Past Medical History:
unknown

[**2184-12-28**] EEG
This is an abnormal awake and sleep EEG because of marked
diffuse attenuation of background with no clearly discernible
cerebral
electrical activity. These findings are indicative of severe
diffuse
encephalopathy which could be due to a variety of causes
including
severe hypoxic/ischemic injury and effects of sedative
medications.
Close clinical monitoring and bedside EEG monitoring is
recommended to
evaluate for change or improvement. Note is made of sinus
tachycardia.

[**2184-12-28**] CT HEAD
1. No acute intracranial process or hemorrhage.
2. 17 mm left planum sphenoidale meningioma.
3. Dense calcification identified below the level of the III
ventricle and
anterior to the cistern of the lamina terminalis the possibility
of a
partially thrombosed aneurysm in the ACA territory is a
consideration,
correlation with MRI and MRA of the with and without contrast is
recommended.

[**2184-12-28**] CT C-SPINE
No fracture or malalignment.

[**2184-12-28**] CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS
The ET tube is a little far advanced and should be retracted a
few
centimeters. There is bibasilar atelectasis plus or minus
consolidation.
There is a fracture of the T12 vertebral body superiorly with an
approximately 10-15% loss of height.
Prominent right ovary-please correlate with mpatients age and
menstruation
history as they become available
No additional findings of note.

[**2184-12-31**] CT HEAD
1. Bilateral regions of cytotoxic edema, concerning for
watershed
infarctions. There is no herniation or diffuse cerebral edema.
Per
discussion with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] (neurology), the patient is already
scheduled to have an MRI.
2. Left sphenoid [**Doctor First Name 362**] meningioma.
3. Dense calcification below the third ventricle raises the
possibility of a partially thrombosed aneurysm unchanged from
[**2184-12-28**]. The patient is
scheduled to undergo an MRI for further evaluation.

[**2184-12-31**] MRI HEAD, MRA BRAIN, MRI NECK
1. Bilateral acute and subacute infarctions in a watershed and
embolic
pattern of distribution.
2. Calcified suprasellar lesion, which could represent a
craniopharyngioma or a thrombosed aneurysm. No definite
connection to the circle of [**Location (un) **] is seen on the MRA.
3. Meningioma in the left sphenoid [**Doctor First Name 362**].
4. Probable cavernoma in the right posterior limb of the
internal capsule.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. [**Last Name (Titles) 50955**] is a 79y/o lady with 2-3 weeks of subtle decline
in mental status who was transferred to [**Hospital1 18**] from an OSH
intubated after a motor vehicle collision.  She did not have any
severe injuries, but was noted to be in a coma despite weaning
off sedation completely.  her neurologic exam fluctuated, with
intermittent loss of brainstem functions (gag, pupillary
reaction).  Neurology was consulted and felt that her exam was
consistent with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.  EEG confirmed
abnormalities, and she was started on antiepileptics.  MRI
suggested watershed infarcts which support the theory of
hypotensive damage, though no hypotension was documented prior
to her transfer.  She was observed for 5 days with minimal
improvement and Neurology believed that her likelihood of a full
recovery was dismal.  Family meetings were held with the MICU
team, patient's niece and nephew [**Doctor Last Name 2048**] and [**Name (NI) 16917**]) as well as
phone conversations with patient's brother [**Name (NI) 122**].  It was
decided that in the case of severe hypoxic damage, she would not
want to be kept alive artificially.  The patient was extubated
on [**2185-1-2**] and expired on [**2185-1-4**]. The case was waived by the
Medical Examiner and an autopsy was not requested by her health
care proxy.
